Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Collaborative Research: RUI: Adaptive Integration of Textual and Geospatial Information for Mining Massive Map Collections

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Libraries and archives are digitizing historical maps for widespread online access. Without technology for searching them, large map collections relevant to a given problem or question may remain obscure even in online archives. If all of the text in a map can be read automatically by computer, a wealth of information becomes quickly available -- location names, geographic features, and often statistics. This project will increase capacity for search and analysis of historical maps by automatically recognizing place names and other text in these digitized artifacts while simultaneously aligning them with modern geography. The improvements this project will make to current text recognition methods will facilitate more powerful uses of humanity's trove of old maps -- for example, by allowing scientists and policymakers to establish changes in land usage, waterways, or borders over time. By creating free, open-source tools for studying historical maps, this project will increase public engagement with science and technology and empower any Internet user to explore the intersection of technology and history. This research will train a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students in constructing, learning, and making predictions with adaptive models featuring heterogeneous yet highly interdependent entities.

Although many institutions are digitizing hundreds of thousands of historical maps, most digitized map images are poorly annotated, limiting their usefulness. Manual annotation and metadata association is highly laborious. This project's primary objectives are (1) to fully automate text and shape-based georeferencing (aligning map images to the known global geography) while (2) indexing words and place names (for search) by enhancing text detection and recognition methods in these complex artifacts. These innovations will address the shortcomings of manual georeferencing and current automated text recognition algorithms. The researchers will employ an iterative interpretation process for solving problems including text/graphics separation, text recognition, and georeferencing. For example, the fact that all members of a given class of text entities on a map (e.g., county names) are typically rendered in the same text style can be used to inform predictions about difficult members of the category with information derived from more easily-recognized members. The researchers will use a dataset of annotated maps containing over 12,000 words in 9,000 place names as benchmark data for testing the algorithms developed in the project. Software, data, and benchmarks will be broadly distributed on the project website (http://www.cs.grinnell.edu/~weinman/research/maps.shtml). Findings will be shared with the research community through journals and conferences in the computer vision, artificial intelligence, and GIS communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our goal was to automate information extraction from digitized historical map images: enabling improved text recognition through modeling underlying cartographic and geographic entities and improved automated alignment of map images to a geographical coordinate system (georeferencing). Success with these outcomes enables new forms of analysis through textual search and broader applicability of hybrid multi-map and geographical visualizations. The award produced several benchmark data sets and code bases for model estimation and comparison, published multiple award-winning papers, and provided research opportunities for a diverse set of undergraduates. Intellectual merits include development of algorithms for robust performance that integrate many information sources to solve a variety of tasks.

 

The award facilitated creation of several data sets with detailed annotations of 31 maps from nine different atlases, covering a key time period (1831--1927) and a variety of scales (1:50,000 to 1:7,500,000), all permanently archived [DOI:11084/19349, DOI:11084/23294, DOI:11084/23330]. The first data set includes over 1,400 annotations of unique geographic identifiers (ANSI INCITS 446-2008) associated with map toponyms [DOI:11084/19495], which is useful for testing how well searches for specific features may perform (rather than generic text). A second data set incorporates exhaustive, detailed character- and word-level bounding boxes for all text, including highway markers and distances [DOI:11084/23294]. These annotations total 32,659 words in 33,868 segments (i.e., where words have wide spacing), and include 2,145 (6.3%) curved text segments, enabling various forms of text detection analysis. Each segment is accurately transcribed (using historical information when legibility was reduced) enabling detailed tests of text recognition methods as well as end-to-end reading (text detection and recognition). The third data set features 6,470 control points referencing map image coordinates to geographical coordinates, enabling training and/or testing of georeferencing methods [DOI:11084/23330].

 

In addition to these data sets, several code repositories have been released as free software [DOI:11084/23320]. These include a trainable deep neural network model for arbitrarily rotated text detection [DOI:11084/23321], a robust and lexicographically-informed deep neural network model for word reading [DOI:11084/23322, DOI:11084/23323], along with a module for automatically synthesizing realistic training text data (for recognition) in the absence of expensive manual annotations [DOI:11084/23324].

 

The data and code are anchored within three peer-reviewed publications resulting from the award. One paper describes an adaptive method for leveraging the consistency between font style and geographical feature category as well as new models for inferring geographical features from the label placement. This work appeared at the IAPR International Conference on Document Analysis and Recognition (ICDAR) in 2017 [DOI:10.1109/ICDAR.2017.160], where it won the Best Paper Award. While that work focused on using additional information to promote text reading accuracy, subsequent work published in ICDAR 2019 contributed the model for detecting texts at arbitrary orientations (important for maps) as well as an updated robust text reading model [DOI:10.1109/ICDAR.2019.00149]. Turning from text, another peer-reviewed paper described a novel approach to automated map georeferencing by aligning modern Geographical Information System (GIS) shapefile data to the map images with deformable part models. This work involved an important generalization of the popular approach from acyclic model graphs to models with dense, loopy connectivity, as often occurs with geographic boundaries or transportation networks. It appeared at the 2019 International Conference on Advances in Geographic Information Systems (ACM SIGSPATIAL), where it won the Best Poster Award [DOI:10.1145/3347146.3359367].

 

Work over the span of the award established several benchmarks and yielded performance improvements on key map information extraction tasks. Compared to prior work, integrating geographic and style models for toponym recognition reduced word recognition errors by 20% and geographic feature identification errors by 32%. The adaptive, text-based approach to georeferencing reduced alignment error by 38%, and the graphics-based approach provided a further 14% reduction?cutting the total alignment error by nearly half (47%) over the span of the award. Other key results include text detection (88% F-measure), word recognition (78% accuracy), end-to-end detection and recognition (64% F-measure), specific place identification (67% accuracy), and georeferencing (6.107 km RMSE).

 

A total of ten undergraduate students---four from traditionally underrepresented groups---were engaged in award-related research. Each received training in research methods and mentoring in their work on the project?previous research by the PI demonstrated the significant value of this particular training [DOI:10.1145/2676723.2677231]. Five traveled to present their results at international conferences, and most received practical training in either GIS (theory and methods) or machine learning (methods and tools). Half of these students are continuing in other summer research or advanced degrees in computer science. Four others have gone or will go into industry upon graduation.

 

In summary, the successful award produced award-winning publications that introduced and improved upon new, difficult benchmarks with algorithmic and modeling advances that increase search and analysis opportunities in historical map collections. Several undergraduates also participated in the scientific process, including international conference presentations.
